text:
86, 84, 80 and 76 Broadway (left to right) at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street, as seen from Trinity Church Yard and viewing eastward to show prominently the 11-story building, No. 80, occupied by the Union Trust Co. For a contemporary view, see, Kings Handbook of New York (1892) page 709.

About 1890.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from a point between
Wall and Pine Street's and across the latter, showing prominently the old Equitable Building occupying the Pine to Cedar Street frontage. This structure erected in 1872, and enlarged in 1887, .contains the main offices of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. To the right is the 5-story structure at the N.E. corner of Pine that was included in the site for the present 21-story American Surety Co. Building. The structure with a clock tower atop and on the far side of the Equitable Building is No.
134-46 Broadway.
This was the former home of the Mutual Life Insurance Company and subsequently occupied by the American Fire Insurance Co. Later the Guaranty Trust Company built there. For a similar illustration-see King's Handbook of New York 1893 page 671.
About 1890
gift of Urbrohk Collection

Broadway, west side, at Wall Street, showing a complete view of Trinity Church. Also shown is a general view of the lower west side of Manhattan, with the Hudson River and lower Bay clearly shown. Note the Statue of Liberty dimly discernible on the right.

About 1895.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

title: Broadway, East Side. Wall to Liberty St.

text:
Broadway, east side, north from a point between Wall and Pine Streets and across the latter showing prominently the Equitable Building occupying the frontage from Pine to Cedar Streets. For a slightly earlier view of this area see Kings Handbook of New York (1893) page 671, also Urbrock Collection - photo of 1890.

About 1900

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

Wall Street, east from Broadway. The trolley tracks are on Broadway.

M.B.R.

1890-1900.

Broadway, east side, from and including Wall Street, to, but not including Exchange Place. No. 1 Wall Street, at the S.E. corner of Broadway, is at the left of Trinity Church.

About 1905.

Irving Underhill.

96-94, 96 and 100 Broadway, east side, north from Wall (right) to Pine (left) Streets, showing 3 structures occupying this entire block front. They are respectively, the First National Bank, the Schermerhorn and the American Surity Buildings.

About 1915.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

North (Hudson) River, at Battery Park, showing the skyline of Lower Manhattan. In the left center background are visible the towers of the Woolworth (left) and Singer Buildings, while in the center, with pyramidal roof is the Bankers Trust Building.

About 1916.

Ewing Galloway.
title: North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - Battery - 14th Street.

text:
Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing the lower stories of four buildings at the S.E. corner that is the site of the present 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building. No. 86-84 is an 18-story structure at the corner. Adjacent to same is an 11-story building, No. 82. Successively in order are the 11-story Central Union Trust Co. at No. 80 and the 21-story Century Building No. 74-72.

About 1928.

Herbert Photos Incorporated.

(1)
Broadway (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Wall Street (left) showing the structures at that location where the huge Irving Trust Company Bldg. will rise. Note to the left of same, the spire of Trinity Church. In the background, prominently seen is the 38 storied Equitable Trust Co. Bldg. The photographer is viewing eastward across the graveyard of the Church, from No. 74 Trinity Place.
May 13, 1929
P. L. Sperr,
(2)
A view from the same vantage point after the aforementioned demolition. Across same appears the rear of the New York Stock Exchange
Building.
Aug. 20, 1929
P. L. Srerr,

(1)
Broadway (foreground), at the S.E. corner of Wall Street (left) showing the structures at that location where the huge Irving Trust Company Bldg. will rise. Note to the left of same, the spire of Trinity Church. In the background, prominently seen is the 38 storied Equitable Trust Co. Bldg. The photographer is viewing eastward across the graveyard of the Church, from No. 74 Trinity Place.
May 13, 1929
P. L. Sperr,
(2)
A view from the same vantage point after the aforementioned demolition. Across same appears the rear of the New York Stock Exchange
Building.
Aug. 20, 1929
P. L. Srerr,

(1) Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing under demolition Nos. 86-84, 82 and 80 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street. These in conjunction with adjoining property formed the site of the present (1937) 50-story Irving Trust Building, known as No. 1 Wall Street. This view is photographed in an eastward direction on Rector Street and shows on the left, the southern edge of Trinity Cemetery, across which appears the 11-story First National Bank, No. 90-94 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. This was demolished and improved with a 21-story structure slightly later. January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) A view solely of the future Irving Trust site as viewed southeastward from in front of Trinity Church (right). January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same as No. 1 at a later date and viewed southeastward. Demolition has been completed for the Irving Trust Co. Building and the steel frame work is rising. On the right appears a clearer view of the First National Bank, No. 90-94, as mentioned in No. 1. August 20, 1929. P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing under demolition Nos. 86-84, 82 and 80 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street. These in conjunction with adjoining property formed the site of the present (1937) 50-story Irving Trust Building, known as No. 1 Wall Street. This view is photographed in an eastward direction on Rector Street and shows on the left, the southern edge of Trinity Cemetery, across which appears the 11-story First National Bank, No. 90-94 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. This was demolished and improved with a 21-story structure slightly later. January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) A view solely of the future Irving Trust site as viewed southeastward from in front of Trinity Church (right). January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same as No. 1 at a later date and viewed southeastward. Demolition has been completed for the Irving Trust Co. Building and the steel frame work is rising. On the right appears a clearer view of the First National Bank, No. 90-94, as mentioned in No. 1. August 20, 1929. P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, showing under demolition Nos. 86-84, 82 and 80 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Wall Street. These in conjunction with adjoining property formed the site of the present (1937) 50-story Irving Trust Building, known as No. 1 Wall Street. This view is photographed in an eastward direction on Rector Street and shows on the left, the southern edge of Trinity Cemetery, across which appears the 11-story First National Bank, No. 90-94 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. This was demolished and improved with a 21-story structure slightly later. January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) A view solely of the future Irving Trust site as viewed southeastward from in front of Trinity Church (right). January 11, 1929. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same as No. 1 at a later date and viewed southeastward. Demolition has been completed for the Irving Trust Co. Building and the steel frame work is rising. On the right appears a clearer view of the First National Bank, No. 90-94, as mentioned in No. 1. August 20, 1929. P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church and Grave Yard that extends westward to Church Street. Excavation in the foreground is for the new 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, No. 1 Wall Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a slightly different angle.

August 7, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church and Grave Yard that extends westward to Church Street. Excavation in the foreground is for the new 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, No. 1 Wall Street.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a slightly different angle.

August 7, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, east side, north from Wall to Pine Streets, August 7, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, in an eastward direction, as seen from No. 74 Trinity Place. The buildings occupying this block front are, the 21-story American Surety Co. Building, No. 100-96 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of Pine Street and the 11-story First National Bank, 94-90 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. The latter was replaced by a 21-story structure in 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

August 20, 1929.

(1) Broadway, east side, north from Wall to Pine Streets, August 7, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, in an eastward direction, as seen from No. 74 Trinity Place. The buildings occupying this block front are, the 21-story American Surety Co. Building, No. 100-96 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of Pine Street and the 11-story First National Bank, 94-90 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Wall Street. The latter was replaced by a 21-story structure in 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

August 20, 1929.

Nos, 2-6 Wall Street, at the N.E. corner of Broadway as viewed across the Irving Trust Co. Building site. This structure, erected in 1880, is occupied by the First National Bank, tho constructed for the National Bank of the Republic, when it was better known as "Fort Sherman." For details see King's Handbook of New York 1893, page 724.

The photographer gives his vantage points as the Stock Exchange (No.1) and the Empire Building (No. 2). Note in the former the partial glimpse of Trinity Cemetery on the opposite side of Broadway.

August 7, 1929
Views 1, 2

P. L. Sperr

Nos, 2-6 Wall Street, at the N.E. corner of Broadway as viewed across the Irving Trust Co. Building site. This structure, erected in 1880, is occupied by the First National Bank, tho constructed for the National Bank of the Republic, when it was better known as "Fort Sherman." For details see King's Handbook of New York 1893, page 724.

The photographer gives his vantage points as the Stock Exchange (No.1) and the Empire Building (No. 2). Note in the former the partial glimpse of Trinity Cemetery on the opposite side of Broadway.

August 7, 1929
Views 1, 2

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Wall Street, east from Trinity Church Yard, which is west
of Broadway.
December 1, 1931.
P.L. Sperr
(2)
The same, prior to the erection of the 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building shown in view 1. On the lower right of this view, the site is shown being prepared. On the opposite corner (shown under demolition in No. 1) is the 11-story First National Bank. Towering over this is the 39-story Bankers Trust Co. Building. The modern type structure in the right background is the 38-story Equitable Trust Co. Building.
August 20, 1929.
P.L. Sperr.

(1)
Wall Street, east from Trinity Church Yard, which is west
of Broadway.

Wall Street, south side, east from Broadway, to and including New Street,
Early 1929.

No. 1 Wall Street, at the S.E. corner of Broadway, as seen from the Church street side of Trinity Church Grave Yard, looking eastward. Building shown is the Irving Trust Company. About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.

Battery Park: A northeastward view towards Broadway from the rear of the Aquarium.  Note the 60 Wall Street Building (Doherty Building) under construction.  No. 2 of this set is from a slightly advanced point of view, while No. 3 is further eastward.
June 18, 1931.
P.L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - Aquarium (rear).

text:
Battery Park: A northeastward view towards Broadway from the rear of the Aquarium.  Note the 60 Wall Street Building (Doherty Building) under construction.  No. 2 of this set is from a slightly advanced point of view, while No. 3 is further eastward.
June 18, 1931.
P.L. Sperr.

text:
Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church and Graveyard extending westward to Trinity Place.

About 1931

Wurts Bros.

No. 1 Wall Street, south side, east from Broadway to New Street, showing the 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, which occupies this site. This is viewed southwestward through the clearance for the Bankers Trust addition and shows the N.E. corner of building concerned.

July 26, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, east side, at Wall Street, as seen across Trinity Church yard and from the N.Y. Curb Exchange Building, showing prominently the 50-story Irving Trust Building, at the S.E. corner of Wall Street and Broadway. Opposite same (left) is the 21-story structure of the First National Bank.

November 25, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing Trinity Church yard.

1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.

Broadway, north from Wall Street, showing mainly the upper portions of structures that line the west side of the Street; prominently of which appear, the spires of Trinity Church and the Woolworth Building. No. 1 is an enlargement by the photographer; No. 2 being a copy of the original negative by the N.Y.P.L.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street. This view of Trinity Church and grounds was photographed southeastward, from a point near Trinity Place and silhouettes the church steeple against No. 50-story Irving Trust Co. Building, at the S.E. corner of Broadway at Wall Street. Shown on the right, are the upper stories of the Empire Building, a 22-story building forming the south side of Rector Street, between Trinity Place and Broadway.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Broadway, west side, at the head of Wall Street, showing a portion of the tower of Trinity Church.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd January 13, 1945
